title.description: A brief title for the rule that should contain what the rule is supposed to detect

id.description: A globally unique identifier for the Sigma rule. This is recommended to be a UUID v4, but not mandatory.

oneOf.description: The rule didn't produce any obvious false positives in multiple environments over a long period of time
The rule doesn't show any obvious false positives on a limited set of test systems
A new rule that hasn't been tested outside of lab environments and could lead to many false positives
The rule was replaced or is now covered by another one. The link between both rules is made via the `related` field
The rule can not be used in its current state (special correlation log, home-made fields, etc.)

description.description: A short description of the rule and the malicious activity that can be detected

author.description: Creator of the rule. (can be a name, nickname, twitter handle, etc.)

references.description: References to the source that the rule was derived from. These could be blog articles, technical papers, presentations or even tweets

date.description: Creation date of the meta rule. Use the ISO 8601 format YYYY-MM-DD

modified.description: Last modification date of the meta rule. Use the ISO 8601 format YYYY-MM-DD

correlation.description: Represents the correlation searched for on the log data

rules.description: Refers to one or multiple Sigma or Correlations rules

aliases.description: Defines field name aliases that are applied to correlated Sigma rules

group-by.description: Defines one or multiple fields which should be treated as separate event occurrence scope

timespan.description: Defines a time period in which the correlation should be applied. Used: `number + letter (in lowercase)`

condition.description: The condition defines when a correlation matches

gt.description: The count must be greater than the given value

gte.description: The count must be greater than or equal to the given value

lt.description: The count must be lesser than the given value

lte.description: The count must be lesser than or equal to the given value

eq.description: The count must be equal to the given value

field.description: Name of the field(s) to count values

falsepositives.description: A list of known false positives that may occur

level.description: The criticality of a triggered rule

oneOf.description: Rule is intended for enrichment of events, e.g. by tagging them. No case or alerting should be triggered by such rules because it is expected that a huge amount of events will match these rules
Notable event but rarely an incident. Low-rated events can be relevant in high numbers or in combination with others. Immediate reaction shouldn't be necessary, but a regular review is recommended
Relevant event that should be reviewed manually on a more frequent basis
Relevant event that should trigger an internal alert and requires a prompt review
Highly relevant event that indicates an incident. Critical events should be reviewed immediately. It is used only for cases in which probability borders certainty

generate.description: Defines if the rules referred to by the correlation rule should be converted into stand-alone rules
